newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkey says PKK rebels massing on border from Iraq.
newsitem.headline: Turkey says PKK rebels massing on border from Iraq.

text.p: Foreign Minister Tansu Ciller said on Wednesday Kurdish separatist rebels in northern Iraq had massed on Turkey's borders and that Ankara would have to take measures to secure its frontiers.
A Foreign Ministry spokesman later said there was no question of sending the Turkish military into northern Iraq to attack the Kurdish guerrillas at the moment.
"We have noted that to a large degree the terrorists have massed on our borders and there could be infiltrations of our borders," Ciller told reporters.

"In such a dangerous situation, Turkey is of course going to ensure border security and stop crossings," she said. "Turkey is going to evaluate what measures it will take with neighbouring countries and do what is necessary."

Ciller was speaking in a news conference about the situation in northern Iraq, where Iraqi troops helped an Iraqi Kurdish faction oust a rival group from the city of Arbil on Saturday, prompting U.S. missile attacks on Iraq on Tuesday and Wednesday.

Up to 35,000 Turkish troops poured into northern Iraq in March 1995 in their biggest cross-border incursion in pursuit of the Kurdistan Workers Party (PKK), which has been fighting for 12 years for control of southeast Turkey.
Ankara says instability in northern Iraq enables the PKK to set up bases there and attack Turkey.
"As of today, no military operation has begun," Foreign Ministry spokesman Omer Akbel later told reporters.
"I believe it is best to interpret (Ciller's) remarks today as a warning to certain people and circles," he said, referring to the PKK.
Akbel said Turkey was ready to take all kinds of precautions in response to the events in northern Iraq.
"It goes without saying that our precautions, as always, will be respectful of Iraq's sovereignty, and its political and territorial integrity," he said.
